item.content:encoded: 1/ If you really believe LLMs will dramatically compress the cost of software development in 3-5 years, doesn't this obviate the reason for independent software vendors to exist? This doesn't seem obviously crazy to me - it'd just be a return to the days of mainframes

item.content:encoded: If you want to have an economics column in the Washington Post, you must rationalize all price hikes‚Äîwithout regard to an industry‚Äôs rising profit margins‚Äîin a manner that shifts the blame away from the companies actually implementing the price hikes. We are entirely helpless.

item.content:encoded: David Sacks: How did we end up in debt? Nobody knows. They will kill you if you ask US Treasury: here is an incredibly detailed website about the national debt https://t.co/SQRNjmUyUp
item.author: BuccoCapital Bloke

item.content:encoded: Can a state agency exercise monopsony power over its employees (e.g., firefighters, police officers, or teachers)? Why, yes. Yes it can. The reason to permit collective bargaining for public (and private) employees is to ensure that workers are paid competitive wages.
item.author: Hal Singer

item.content:encoded: Elon and his Tech Nazis are accessing your personal data illegally, and there IS something you can do about it. Contact your state's Attorney General, or your Consumer Protection Agency here: https://t.co/OohvzjqsD1. Fight back.

item.content:encoded: Have revisited this passage hundreds of times; It describes what it takes to make big money better than anything I‚Äôve ever read.
item.author: Sidecar Investor

item.content:encoded: While the majority of Intel's foundry revenue is intersegment, it accounts for 25% of revenue and 50% of costs and 28% of OPEX (if considered as a stand-alone unit). Foundry is the largest COGS/OPEX segment and 2nd largest revenue segment for Intel.
item.author: Sravan Kundojjala

item.content:encoded: You don't need to be a coder to figure this out. Simply type: tab age You'll discover a smattering of 99 year olds, a few 100 year olds, a couple of 101 year olds, and a pileup of 150 year olds, but no-one in their 130s or 140s. That's a clear sign you've discovered a coding

item.content:encoded: It is not a coincidence that every single one of the tech billionaires trying to destroy the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has a lot to gain from a less informed, less protected consumer
item.author: BuccoCapital Bloke

item.content:encoded: Something that surprised me on my trip to China last year was how everybody ordered food via WeChat even when dining in at a restaurant Turns out WeChat now processes $300B/year of these orders. 50% of dine-in spend in China is now via phone instead of talking to a waiter
item.author: Corry Wang

item.content:encoded: In a time of increased inequality and technology-induced dislocations, workers need a place to get a footing at the beginning of their careers (as I did at the SEC) or a place to shift into in response to a shock. We should be *adding* public-sector jobs, not destroying them.

item.content:encoded: Sigh. The New York Times runs another essay with a provocative title about reforming the Democratic Party but falls short of a compelling vision. Enough with the appeals to ‚Äúdynamic‚Äù aka Silicon Valley ‚Äúbusiness leaders.‚Äù If this is the vision of incumbents, we need a new party.

item.content:encoded: Completely correct. The rise of AI search, which doesn't throw ad-supported traffic, will lead to either gating of a lot of information, or some type of payments system. Perhaps: AI agents with access to X will recommend paying for access to X, solving Arrow's info paradox.
